items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: A Catalyst for New York City’s Rebirth
items.abstract: The architect Peter Samton reflects on the legacy of Ada Louise Huxtable, onetime architecture critic for The New York Times.

items.title: Assembly Leader Softens on Placing Casino in New York City
items.abstract: Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, said he remained opposed to a casino with table games in Manhattan, but would be open to one in other areas of the city.

items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: Quirks of Amsterdam, Revealed During Lunch
items.abstract: A midday stroll near the author’s office tells a story of a city defined by water.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: What Planners of Brooklyn-Queens Streetcar Line Can Learn in New Jersey
items.abstract: The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail, across the river from New York City, offers a look at the benefits and challenges of a street-level transit line.

items.title: Challenging Washington’s Architectural History
items.abstract: Architectural diversity on Washington's National Mall is in full flower.

items.title: What Made New York New York? Henry Hudson, George Washington and a Silver Subway Shovel
items.abstract: The Museum of the City of New York is preparing a major exhibition, opening in November, that spans the city’s four-century story of growth and transformation.
keywords: Museum of the City of New York

items.title: New York Today: Tribeca Takes the City
items.abstract: Wednesday: The Tribeca Film Festival, sunny weather and other film events around the city.

items.title: Massapequa Park, N.Y.: A Homey Village Amid Suburban Sprawl
items.abstract: Buyers will find a range of options in this village on the South Shore of Long Island, from modest starter homes to large waterfront houses with docks.

items.title: ‘It’s the Human Way’: Corruption Scandals Play Out in Big Cities Across U.S.
items.abstract: Major federal corruption investigations have brought dark clouds to Los Angeles, Chicago, Atlanta and Philadelphia.

items.title: The Forbidden City Offers a Rare Nighttime Glimpse of China’s Imperial Past
items.abstract: The Beijing palace and temple complex opened its doors to the public at night for the first time since 1925, giving visitors the chance to see it bathed in electric light.

items.title: What to See in New York City This Spring
items.abstract: Broadway, Wagner’s “Ring,” the opening of the Shed: what our critics and writers are looking forward to this season.

items.title: Solving the Problems of Rural America
items.abstract: Readers react to Paul Krugman’s statement that “nobody knows how to reverse” the economic decline of the heartland.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
items.abstract: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.

items.title: The Next Affordable City Is Already Too Expensive
items.abstract: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?

items.title: In Detroit, a Bet That Healthy Restaurants Can Help the City
items.abstract: For years, a coalition of groups has supported food businesses, seeing them as critical to the city’s continuing recovery. The pandemic has put its accomplishments to the test.

items.title: Hidden Tampa: The Best of an Often-Overlooked Florida City
items.abstract: From a Buddhist temple reached by boat to a storied hotel and a speakeasy bar: a cheat sheet on what to do in this Gulf Coast city, which has found new fans during the pandemic.
